abstract: Japan’s industrial production fell at the fastest rate in at least five years in August, the unemployment rate rose and household spending tumbled, deepening the slump in the country’s economy.
snippet: Japan’s industrial production fell at the fastest rate in at least five years in August, the unemployment rate rose and household spending tumbled, deepening the slump in the country’s economy.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s industrial production fell at the fastest rate in at least five years in August, the unemployment rate rose and household spending tumbled, deepening the slump in the country’s economy. Factory output dropped 3.5 percent from July, the country’s Trade Ministry said. The jobless rate climbed to a two-year high of 4.2 percent, and household spending slumped 4 percent, the most since September 2006, the government said. Japan may already be in a recession as the economic problems in the United States weaken exports and demand at home plummets because of rising prices and the deteriorating labor market. “Japan has one leg in a serious recession,” said Masamichi Adachi, senior economist at JPMorgan Chase in Tokyo. “We have to lower our growth forecasts for Japan this year given today’s numbers.”

headline.main: Japan: Data Indicates Slowdown

lead_paragraph: Unemployment in Ireland rose in September to the highest level in 11 years as the housing slump and global credit crisis curbed economic growth and hiring. Benefit applications, adjusted for seasonal swings, increased to 244,500, the highest since December 1997, from 235,100 in August, the Central Statistics Office said. abstract: The Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group will take a 9.9 percent stake in Aberdeen Asset Management and distribute the company’s products in Japan.
snippet: The Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group will take a 9.9 percent stake in Aberdeen Asset Management and distribute the company’s products in Japan.
lead_paragraph: The Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group will take a 9.9 percent stake in Aberdeen Asset Management, Scotland’s largest independent money manager, and distribute the company’s products in Japan. Mitsubishi UFJ will pay 20 billion yen ($190 million) for the stake, the company said. The bank said it would raise its stake to 19.9 percent by next spring. The deal with Aberdeen follows Mitsubishi UFJ’s agreement to pay $9 billion to buy a 21 percent stake in Morgan Stanley on Sept. 29, as the second-largest American securities firm sought to shore up investor confidence after borrowing costs climbed and its stock fell by half. The bank has agreed not raise its stake beyond 19.9 percent for the next 18 months, Aberdeen said.

headline.main: Japan: Bank Invests in Money Manager
headline.print_headline: JAPAN: BANK INVESTS IN MONEY MANAGER

abstract: Singapore’s private home prices fell for the first time in more than four years in the third quarter, signaling an end to a real estate boom that began in 2004.
snippet: Singapore’s private home prices fell for the first time in more than four years in the third quarter, signaling an end to a real estate boom that began in 2004.
lead_paragraph: Singapore’s private home prices fell for the first time in more than four years in the third quarter, signaling an end to a real estate boom that began in 2004. Prices declined 1.8 percent in the three months ended Sept. 30, after rising 0.2 percent in the second quarter, the Urban Redevelopment Authority said. That is the first drop since the three months ended March 31, 2004, when prices retreated 0.4 percent, according to the agency. The 17-quarter rally in home prices stalled amid concern soaring inflation and the global credit crisis would hurt the city’s economic growth. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said on Aug. 8 that Singapore’s economy would expand 4 percent to 5 percent, less than an earlier estimate of 4 percent to 6 percent.

headline.main: Singapore: Home Prices Decline
headline.print_headline: SINGAPORE: HOME PRICES DECLINE

abstract: E.On Ruhrgas, a German utility, and Gazprom signed a deal giving E.On Ruhrgas a stake in the Yuzhno-Russkoye natural gas field in Siberia.
snippet: E.On Ruhrgas, a German utility, and Gazprom signed a deal giving E.On Ruhrgas a stake in the Yuzhno-Russkoye natural gas field in Siberia.
lead_paragraph: E.On Ruhrgas, a German utility, and Gazprom signed a deal giving E.On Ruhrgas a stake in the Yuzhno-Russkoye natural gas field in Siberia. In return, E.On Ruhrgas will reduce its minority stake in the Russian gas monopoly by nearly half. Under the terms of the accord, E.On will obtain a 25 percent stake in the Yuzhno-Russkoye field, which, according to Gazprom, has recoverable reserves of about 600 billion cubic meters of natural gas. In return, Gazprom will receive 49 percent of E.On’s stake in the Russian energy trading company Gerosgas. Gerosgas has a stake in Gazprom, of which nearly 3 percent is held by E.On. The asset swap means that E.On will relinquish that stake, thus reducing its total stake in Gazprom to 3.5 percent. Russia supplies more than 35 percent of Germany’s natural gas needs.

headline.main: Germany: Utility Gets Part of Gas Field
headline.print_headline: GERMANY: UTILITY GETS PART OF GAS FIELD

lead_paragraph: One of the most coveted of workplace perks is the sabbatical or leave of absence — a way to stray from your job for a time and return with renewed vigor and enthusiasm. To those of us outside academia, however, leaves of absence are rare. Still, leaves of absence can make good sense — for both an employer and employee. Even in dismal economic times like now. Today we have a guest post by Barbara Raab, who is currently on a leave of absence from her job at NBC News. She says that before she asked for the time off, she, too, thought leaves of absence were more fantasy than reality. — Marci

headline.main: Finessing a Leave of Absence

abstract: Caddies are turning into concierges with an expertise in areas beyond golf, like the local flora and fauna.
snippet: Caddies are turning into concierges with an expertise in areas beyond golf, like the local flora and fauna.
lead_paragraph: I TRUDGED down the fifth fairway at the Ritz-Carlton Golf Club in Orlando, Fla., with a golf bag on my shoulder and a royal blue bib draped over my chest. It was a near perfect day, temperature in the low 80s with a slight breeze, the sky puffed with cottony clouds. But for once, I, the former would-be tour pro, wasn’t playing the game. I was in executive pursuit of becoming a so-called caddie concierge. The bag I was toting belonged to Forrest Kvemshagen, a hotel guest with a 24.5 handicap who was chief information officer for a Canadian government agency. A veteran caddie concierge named Bob Blegen was riding in a golf cart with Forrest’s wife, Pat Ryland, a 30 handicapper. The Ritz’s director of golf operations, Patrick Dill, was walking a few paces behind us to evaluate my performance.

headline.main: This Caddie Knows a Birdie From an Osprey

snippet: The false report on a CNN citizen journalist site said that Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, had a heart attack and was hospitalized.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the origin of a false report on a CNN citizen journalist Web site that Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, left, had a heart attack and was hospitalized. The agency’s enforcement unit is trying to determine whether the posting, which was on iReport.com, was intended to push down the company’s stock price. CNN is cooperating with the S.E.C.’s inquiry, a network spokeswoman, Jennifer Martin, said. The report is “not true,” an Apple spokesman, Steve Dowling, said. John Heine, a spokesman for the S.E.C., declined to comment.

headline.main: S.E.C. Investigates Web Report on Apple
headline.print_headline: S.E.C. Investigates Web Report On Apple

abstract: UBS, the Swiss bank, raised its stake in Parmalat, the Italian food company, to 5.1 percent, making it the biggest investor in the company.
snippet: UBS, the Swiss bank, raised its stake in Parmalat, the Italian food company, to 5.1 percent, making it the biggest investor in the company.
lead_paragraph: UBS, the Swiss bank, raised its stake in Parmalat, the Italian food company, to 5.1 percent, making it the biggest investor in the company. UBS, based in Zurich, increased its holding from 2.6 percent on Sept. 25, according to a filing with Italian stock market regulator, Consob. Rebeca Garcia, a UBS spokeswoman, said the holding was “not a strategic investment.” Parmalat had no comment. Parmalat collapsed in December 2003 in Italy’s biggest bankruptcy. Investigators later discovered debt had topped more than 14 billion euros ($19 billion), or about eight times the amount previously reported.

headline.main: Swiss Bank UBS Raises Stake in Parmalat
headline.print_headline: Swiss Bank UBS Raises Stake In Parmalat

abstract: InBev, the world’s biggest brewer, and a smaller rival, Carlsberg, reported weakening sales in Russia.
snippet: InBev, the world’s biggest brewer, and a smaller rival, Carlsberg, reported weakening sales in Russia.
lead_paragraph: InBev, the world’s biggest brewer, and a smaller rival, Carlsberg, reported weakening sales in Russia as cold weather and turmoil in financial markets affect demand for beer in one of their fastest-growing markets. Carlsberg, the Nordic region’s largest brewery, fell 6.2 percent in Copenhagen trading, while InBev dropped 4 percent in Brussels. Third-quarter volume sales in Russia declined “slightly” because of cool weather, according to Carlsberg, the country’s market leader. InBev said that Russian demand was slowing as drinkers shunned lower-priced brews. Carlsberg said the Russian beer market shrank “slightly” in the third quarter, mostly because of “exceptionally poor weather.”

headline.main: Beer Sales Down in Russia
headline.print_headline: Beer Sales Down In Russia

abstract: British Airways said first- and business-class travel fell 8.6 percent last month.
snippet: British Airways said first- and business-class travel fell 8.6 percent last month.
lead_paragraph: British Airways said first- and business-class travel fell 8.6 percent last month as the credit crisis and economic slowdown led to job losses and tighter budgets in the City of London and Wall Street. Overall traffic declined 4.8 percent from a year earlier, the airline said. Load factor, a measure of seat occupancy, fell 4.3 percentage points, to 74 percent. Premium traffic increased 2.2 percent in August. “Trading conditions continue to be challenging,” British Airways said. “Long-haul premium traffic has softened after the summer and forward bookings are being affected by the increased anxiety in financial markets and by the uncertain economic outlook.”

headline.main: Luxury Travel Declines at British Airways
headline.print_headline: Luxury Travel Declines at British Airways

Now, the central bank is pushing banks like Kaupthing, the nation’s largest, to use their euro reserves and sell foreign assets. It may not be enough. The central bank needs to bolster its inadequate stock of euros to act as the lender of last resort.

lead_paragraph: Citigroup won regulatory approval to open two lending companies to provide loans to rural residents in Hubei Province in central China. The provincial branch of the China Banking Regulatory Commission approved the Citibank (China) Company’s formation of the Hubei Jingzhou Gong’an Citi Lending Company and the Hubei Xian’ning Chibi Citi Lending Company. The two companies, which will offer secured and unsecured loans without taking deposits, will start operations “within months,” the bank said. HSBC and Standard Charter also are opening rural branches in China.

abstract: Hypo Real Estate Holding, a commercial property lender, said its chief executive, Georg Funke, is stepping down just days after the German government arranged a $68 billion bailout for the company.
snippet: Hypo Real Estate Holding, a commercial property lender, said its chief executive, Georg Funke, is stepping down just days after the German government arranged a $68 billion bailout for the company.
lead_paragraph: Hypo Real Estate Holding, a commercial property lender, said its chief executive, Georg Funke, is stepping down just days after the German government arranged a 50 billion-euro ($68 billion) bailout for the company. Hypo, based in Munich, said Mr. Funke, 53, was leaving immediately. Axel Wieandt, currently head of corporate development and corporate investments at Deutsche Bank, will succeed him on Monday. The bailout came after a weekend of talks with the government after the country’s banks and insurers backed out of a 35 billion-euro rescue package. Both the government and the Bundesbank have said Hypo Real Estate, Germany’s second-biggest property lender, is too big to fail.

headline.main: Germany: Executive Resigns
headline.print_headline: GERMANY: EXECUTIVE RESIGNS

abstract: British factory production fell 0.4 percent in August, contracting for a sixth consecutive month in the worst streak for almost three decades, the Office for National Statistics said.
snippet: British factory production fell 0.4 percent in August, contracting for a sixth consecutive month in the worst streak for almost three decades, the Office for National Statistics said.
lead_paragraph: British factory production fell 0.4 percent in August, contracting for a sixth consecutive month in the worst streak for almost three decades, the Office for National Statistics said. The last time factory production fell for at least six consecutive months was in 1980. Factory production dropped 1.9 percent from a year earlier, the most since 2003. Ten out of 13 categories of manufacturing fell on the month, led by automakers, the statistics office said.

headline.main: Britain: Factory Output Down
headline.print_headline: BRITAIN: FACTORY OUTPUT DOWN

abstract: The carmaker Daimler said sales for its Mercedes-Benz brand declined 3 percent in September, although the company booked a 4 percent gain in car sales for the first nine months of the year.
snippet: The carmaker Daimler said sales for its Mercedes-Benz brand declined 3 percent in September, although the company booked a 4 percent gain in car sales for the first nine months of the year.
lead_paragraph: The carmaker Daimler said sales for its Mercedes-Benz brand declined 3 percent in September, although the company booked a 4 percent gain in car sales for the first nine months of the year. Daimler, based in Stuttgart, said it sold 110,700 Mercedes-Benz brand cars worldwide in September, down from 114,100 in September 2007. The Mercedes-Benz brand includes the compact Smart models as well as the superluxury Maybach cars. In the first nine months of 2008, Mercedes-Benz sold 979,800 vehicles, compared with 942,300 a year earlier.

headline.main: Germany: Mercedes Sales Fall
headline.print_headline: GERMANY: MERCEDES SALES FALL

abstract: Banco Español de Crédito, the Spanish lender owned by Banco Santander, said third-quarter profit rose 5.6 percent as higher lending revenue more than offset an increase in defaults.
snippet: Banco Español de Crédito, the Spanish lender owned by Banco Santander, said third-quarter profit rose 5.6 percent as higher lending revenue more than offset an increase in defaults.
lead_paragraph: Banco Español de Crédito, the Spanish lender owned by Banco Santander, said third-quarter profit rose 5.6 percent as higher lending revenue more than offset an increase in defaults. Net income was 204.4 million euros ($278 million), compared with 193.6 million euros in the period a year earlier. The profitability of Spanish banks is under pressure from a surge in loan defaults as the collapse of a 10-year property boom threatens to pitch the economy into a recession. Banco Español de Crédito said lending declined and arrears as a portion of total loans reached 1.17 percent, from 0.79 percent in June and 0.43 percent a year ago. Lending growth slumped to an annual 3.6 percent, from almost 11 percent in June and 25 percent a year ago. Commercial lending plunged 16 percent; asset-backed lending, including mortgages, rose 1.1 percent.

headline.main: Spain: Profit Up at Bank
headline.print_headline: SPAIN: PROFIT UP AT BANK

lead_paragraph: John Mack, the chief of Morgan Stanley, lobbied for the current ban on short sales of financial stocks. But that didn’t keep the former investment bank’s shares from plunging 25 percent Tuesday. Rumors  which the company said were unfounded  about the fate of Morgan Stanley’s expected $9 billion injection from the Japanese bank Mitsubishi UFJ were partly to blame. Russian exchanges have lost more than two-thirds of their value since their highs in May.

abstract: Industrial production in Germany, Europe’s largest economy, rose the most in 15 years in August, led by demand for construction.
snippet: Industrial production in Germany, Europe’s largest economy, rose the most in 15 years in August, led by demand for construction.
lead_paragraph: Industrial production in Germany, Europe’s largest economy, rose the most in 15 years in August, led by demand for construction. Output gained a seasonally adjusted 3.4 percent from July, when it slipped 1.6 percent, the Economy Ministry in Berlin said Wednesday. That is the biggest gain since August 1993. Economists expected a drop of 0.3 percent, the median of 27 forecasts in a Bloomberg News survey showed. From a year earlier, production adjusted for working days rose 1.7 percent. The German economy has shown few signs of recovery after shrinking in the second quarter, as worsening financial market turmoil pushes up credit costs and weighs on global growth. Still, factory orders rose for the first time in nine months in August and investors were more optimistic last month. “It wasn’t much of a surprise after factory orders,” said Sylvain Broyer, an economist at Natixis in Frankfurt. “We’re only at the beginning of a slowdown. The German economy will fail to grow over the coming one or two quarters.” Factory orders rose for the first time in nine months in August, data showed Wednesday, ending their longest-ever losing streak. The August gain in industrial production is distorted because of the summer holidays, the Economy Ministry said.

headline.main: Germany: Industrial Production Rises
headline.print_headline: GERMANY: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION RISES

abstract: Brazil’s monthly inflation rate dropped in September to the lowest in a year as food prices fell for a second month.
snippet: Brazil’s monthly inflation rate dropped in September to the lowest in a year as food prices fell for a second month.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s monthly inflation rate dropped in September to the lowest in a year as food prices fell for a second month. Consumer price increases, as measured by the benchmark IPCA index, slowed to 0.26 percent in September, down from 0.28 percent in the previous month, the fourth straight monthly decline. Still, the increase in September was more than the 0.20 percent median forecast in a Bloomberg survey of 34 economists. Central bank policy makers last month signaled that they were ready to slow the pace of interest rate increases, saying declining commodity prices and slower world economic growth will help control inflation in Brazil. Food prices fell 0.27 percent in September, the second straight month of food deflation. In August, food prices fell 0.18 percent.

headline.main: Brazil: Inflation Rate Falls
headline.print_headline: BRAZIL: INFLATION RATE FALLS

abstract: Groupe Caisse d’Epargne and Groupe Banque Populaire, the French lenders that control Natixis, are in talks to merge as the global financial crisis pushes banks to combine.
snippet: Groupe Caisse d’Epargne and Groupe Banque Populaire, the French lenders that control Natixis, are in talks to merge as the global financial crisis pushes banks to combine.
lead_paragraph: Groupe Caisse d’Epargne and Groupe Banque Populaire, the French lenders that control Natixis, are in talks to merge as the global financial crisis pushes banks to combine. The merger would create a network of 8,200 agencies in France with 40 billion euros ($54.6 billion) of shareholder equity and 480 billion euros of savings and deposits, according to a statement Wednesday from Caisse d’Epargne. The bank would rank second to Crédit Agricole by number of branches and have combined revenue of 17.5 billion euros. French officials have encouraged the merger in order to bolster capital and restore confidence among depositors and shareholders of Natixis as the global credit crisis worsens. President Nicolas Sarkozy of France two days ago summoned a meeting of French finance and insurance executives and has called for greater supervision in the industry. “Caisse d’Epargne and Banque Populaire need to take action for themselves and for Natixis,” said Anis Bouayad, Paris-based founder of AB Conseils, which advises companies on strategy.

headline.main: France: Merger Talks for Lenders
headline.print_headline: FRANCE: MERGER TALKS FOR LENDERS

abstract: Volvo has tripled the number of planned job cuts to 6,000 positions, or 25 percent of its work force, citing a “rapidly deteriorating” auto market.
snippet: Volvo has tripled the number of planned job cuts to 6,000 positions, or 25 percent of its work force, citing a “rapidly deteriorating” auto market.
lead_paragraph: Volvo has tripled the number of planned job cuts to 6,000 positions, or 25 percent of its work force, citing a “rapidly deteriorating” auto market. “The unstable economic environment has resulted in a very unpredictable situation, and the downturn in the global car industry is more drastic than expected,” Stephen Odell, Volvo’s chief executive, said Wednesday in a statement. Earnings for this year’s second half at Volvo, a division of the Ford Motor Company, will be worse than in the first six months, Ford said last week, reversing a forecast for improvement. The Swedish unit had a pretax loss of $271 million in the first half of 2008.Volvo said the positions include regular employees and consultants. Volvo has 24,300 employees. The job cuts are part of a plan to lower expenses by 4 billion kronor ($562 million). Ford bought the car brand in March 1999.

headline.main: Sweden: More Job Cuts at Volvo
headline.print_headline: SWEDEN: MORE JOB CUTS AT VOLVO

abstract: Canadian new-home starts unexpectedly rose in September, the second straight monthly increase, led by new condominiums in cities.
snippet: Canadian new-home starts unexpectedly rose in September, the second straight monthly increase, led by new condominiums in cities.
lead_paragraph: Canadian new-home starts unexpectedly rose in September, the second straight monthly increase, led by new condominiums in cities. The September total of 217,600 units on an annualized basis compares with a revised 217,400 the month before, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation said on Wednesday. Economists said home starts would drop to 205,000 units, the median of 18 responses in a Bloomberg survey. Housing and construction in Canada, while slowing, are not tumbling even as near record home prices, mortgage costs and tight credit conditions make real estate purchases harder for families and companies.

headline.main: Canada: New Home Starts Increase

lead_paragraph: CAI, the Italian investor group, is beginning talks this week to sell a stake in Alitalia to Air France-KLM Group or Deutsche Lufthansa. CAI, led by businessman Roberto Colaninno, is leading a rescue to merge Alitalia’s flight business with Air One, a competitor, leaving the Italian government to liquidate Alitalia’s debt and other assets. The Italian government has been trying to sell its 49.9 percent stake in Alitalia for almost two years and both Air France and Lufthansa have participated in failed auctions for the airline.

headline.main: Italy: Talks Begin on Alitalia

abstract: India’s largest outsourcing firm, Tata Consultancy Services, is buying Citigroup’s back-office operations in India for $505 million in cash, the companies said on Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: India’s largest outsourcing firm, Tata Consultancy Services, is buying Citigroup’s back-office operations in India for $505 million in cash, the companies said on Wednesday. Citigroup is also giving Tata Consultancy a $2.5 billion, nine-and-a-half-year contract to provide outsourcing services to Citi and its affiliates. Citigroup, suffering from $61 billion in credit-related write-downs, has been trying to sell off noncore assets. Citigroup’s back-office operations have more than 12,000 employees in India and are expected to have revenue of $278 million in 2008.

headline.main: India: Tata to Buy Citigroup Operations

lead_paragraph: I got a note today from Ray Fair, an economist at Yale who’s best known for his mathematical formula that uses economic variables to forecast presidential elections. (It is now predicting roughly a four-point Obama win.) He is also the father of Emily Oster, a University of Chicago economist, and the husband of Sharon Oster, another Yale economist. It seems the elder Professor Oster may have played a small, present-at-the-creation role in the current financial crisis. Professor Fair writes:

headline.main: Is It All Sharon Oster’s Fault?

It is the latest sign that the downturn is going to temper the mood in always-upbeat Silicon Valley.

abstract: That is what CNBC says about a week that saw the market drop by some 18 percent. Every day brought yet another triple digit loss, the worst being Thursday’s 679-point drop. It turns out that preventing crashes is something we’re just not able to learn from history.

lead_paragraph: The stock market is bouncing back Monday because, perhaps in honor of Columbus Day, the government has discovered the new world of nationalizing (at least partly) the banks. abstract: Regulators are moving toward auctioning a block of spectrum for use by companies that want to offer free wireless data service. This may be good for consumers, but is it fair?
snippet: Regulators are moving toward auctioning a block of spectrum for use by companies that want to offer free wireless data service. This may be good for consumers, but is it fair?
lead_paragraph: I like free stuff as much as the next guy. And I certainly don’t have any interest in telecom oligopolies being able to raise prices without competition. But there is something that strikes me as unfair about the Federal Communications Commission’s plan to auction off a block of spectrum under the specific proviso that it be used to offer free wireless service to the public.

headline.main: Is Free Wireless Data Fair?

abstract: The police surrounded Pakistan’s biggest stock exchange to thwart violence by investors demanding a trading halt.
snippet: The police surrounded Pakistan’s biggest stock exchange to thwart violence by investors demanding a trading halt.
lead_paragraph: The police surrounded Pakistan’s biggest stock exchange to thwart violence by investors demanding a trading halt as price curbs imposed after the biggest slump in a decade locked up their money. “There are no longer any small investors left in the stock market, they have all been destroyed,” said Kausar Qaimkhani, chairman of the Small Investors Association, leading a group of about 50 shareholders outside the Karachi Stock Exchange. “The market should be closed till funds are arranged.” Board members of the exchange are deciding whether to extend six-week-old rules that prevented stocks from falling below their Aug. 27 closing prices after rejecting calls from brokers to shut the market. The benchmark Karachi Stock Exchange 100 index rose 2.89, or 0.03 percent, to 9,184.24 at the 2:15 p.m. local time close.

headline.main: Pakistan: Protests at Exchange

abstract: Remember three years ago, when Overstock’s chief executive, Patrick M. Byrne, sued a short-seller named David Rocker and a small independent research outfit, Gradient? abstract: A new documentary film explores the tension between being a mother and building a career as an artist.

lead_paragraph: These statistics, cited in a new documentary film, sound alarmingly like the numbers released by organizations that track the presence of women in the highest echelons of professions like law, journalism, engineering or finance. Yet, outside the art world, few people talk about the difficulties that female artists face when rising up in the ranks. As in these other fields, experts say the reason there are fewer women at the top is largely because of the difficulties in establishing or maintaining a careers while also raising children.

headline.main: Artist/Mother, an Uneasy Marriage

abstract: There are a number of reasons that the former Federal Reserve chairman Paul A. Volcker would be the ideal choice to be the next Treasury secretary.
snippet: There are a number of reasons that the former Federal Reserve chairman Paul A. Volcker would be the ideal choice to be the next Treasury secretary.
lead_paragraph: I do not know about you, but I was both surprised and pleased to hear during the presidential debate this week that the Democratic candidate, Barack Obama, was relying on the former Federal Reserve chairman Paul A. Volcker for advice during the financial crisis. I was surprised because I did not realize that Mr. Volcker, who had been an extremely nonpartisan Fed chairman before Alan Greenspan, did that sort of thing — roll up his sleeves in the middle of a heated campaign. I always had the sense that he preferred to be above the political fray.

headline.main: Paul Volcker for Treasury Secretary

abstract: Honeywell International cut its fourth-quarter profit forecast and said it would brace for “recessionary conditions” in the United States and Europe next year. Third-quarter profit increased to $719 million, or 97 cents a share, from $618 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier. That topped the average Wall Street estimate by 2 cents, according to Reuters Estimates. Revenue rose 6.2 percent, to $9.28 billion. Honeywell now expects to earn 97 cents to $1.01 a share on revenue of $9.4 billion in the fourth quarter. Analysts, on average, had looked for profit of $1.04 a share on sales of $9.8 billion.
snippet: Honeywell International cut its fourth-quarter profit forecast and said it would brace for “recessionary conditions” in the United States and Europe next year. Third-quarter profit increased to $719 million, or 97 cents a share, from $618 million,...
lead_paragraph: General Motors, looking to raise cash as sales slump in the United States, said it had started distributing financial information to potential buyers of its Hummer Sport Utility Vehicle Unit. The automaker “has had interest from a few parties,” said Joanne Krell, a spokeswoman for G.M.,. in an interview. She declined to name them. G.M. has not set a date for a possible sale of Hummer and is still considering other options for the division, Ms. Krell said. Selling Hummer would help G.M. meet its goal of increasing its cash by $15 billion by the end of 2009. Hummer’s domestic sales this year through September declined 47 percent, more than double G.M.’S. 18 percent drop, as high gasoline prices curbed demand. G.M.,. which is based in Detroit, hired Citigroup for a review of the unit, which began in June. Hummer sales peaked in 2006 at 71,524 vehicles before dropping 22 percent last year, according to Autodata.

headline.main: G.M. Sends Out Financial Data on Its Hummer Unit
headline.print_headline: G.M. Sends Out Financial Data on Its Hummer Unit

abstract: Daniel Alpert’s plan to help homeowners with impaired mortgages, which was the subject of my column on Saturday, received many thoughtful comments. Many readers were as enthusiastic about his plan as I was, but many others raised objections that deserve to be addressed. I asked Mr. Alpert to respond to the critics. Here is what he wrote:I greatly appreciate all the comments and e-mails I received this weekend about the Freedom Recovery Plan (FRP). They reflect considerable thought and attention from respondents from all over the country. It is clear that this is a subject that resonates profoundly and with great emotion. For those who are just coming to this debate now, you can read my detailed description of the plan here. (It’s the document on the bottom right.)
lead_paragraph: Daniel Alpert’s plan to help homeowners with impaired mortgages, which was the subject of my column on Saturday, received many thoughtful comments. Many readers were as enthusiastic about his plan as I was, but many others raised objections that deserve to be addressed. I asked Mr. Alpert to respond to the critics. Here is what he wrote:I greatly appreciate all the comments and e-mails I received this weekend about the Freedom Recovery Plan (FRP). They reflect considerable thought and attention from respondents from all over the country. It is clear that this is a subject that resonates profoundly and with great emotion. For those who are just coming to this debate now, you can read my detailed description of the plan here. (It’s the document on the bottom right.)

headline.main: The Freedom Recovery Plan: Daniel Alpert Responds

abstract: In praise of Google Docs, a free Internet-based word processing application that also allows for offline use.
snippet: In praise of Google Docs, a free Internet-based word processing application that also allows for offline use.
lead_paragraph: I recently bought a MacBook Air so that I could have an ultra lightweight computer for traveling and for days when I need to work outside my home office. Because it’s my second computer, I didn’t want to spend money on software. Whenever I used it to create documents, I figured I’d just work in “the cloud,” meaning that I’d store things on the Internet rather than on the computer’s hard drive. I was already a heavy user of Google Docs, a free word-processing application that allows users to easily share documents with other people. So I thought I’d just use that as my word processing program on the new computer. Then I started worrying — did I really want to rely on being able to get Internet access every time I wanted to work on a document?

headline.main: Computing in the Cloud, With Suspenders

You might even call the seeming reluctance of the Justice Department to okay Yahoo’s deal to have Google sell some of its ads a mixed blessing, at least for Google. Now that Microsoft doesn’t seem to want to buy Yahoo, a blocked deal could leave Yahoo, Google’s biggest rival, to wither with no savior in sight.

abstract: Here is another idea for stopping the wave of foreclosures and doing something about the financial crisis at the retail level — i.e. the homeowner — rather than the wholesale level — the banking system. It comes from William R. Hambrecht, a lifelong out-of-the-box thinker, and founder of W.R. Hambrecht & Company, which takes companies public using a Dutch auction method instead of the traditional fee-laden, insider-driven Wall Street process.For those of you just joining this “Should Homeowners Be Rescued?” discussion, here is my column on the subject. And here are the details of the proposed Freedom Recovery Plan, which I wrote about on Saturday. (It is the document on the bottom right.) The Hambrecht Plan involves, fundamentally, a debt-for-equity swap at the residential housing level. Like the Freedom Recovery Plan, its primary aim is to prevent foreclosures and keep people in their homes, while acknowledging that housing prices will surely have to decline further before any kind of recovery can begin. I’ll let Mr. Hambrecht take it from here.
lead_paragraph: Here is another idea for stopping the wave of foreclosures and doing something about the financial crisis at the retail level — i.e. the homeowner — rather than the wholesale level — the banking system. It comes from William R. Hambrecht, a lifelong out-of-the-box thinker, and founder of W.R. Hambrecht & Company, which takes companies public using a Dutch auction method instead of the traditional fee-laden, insider-driven Wall Street process.For those of you just joining this “Should Homeowners Be Rescued?” discussion, here is my column on the subject. And here are the details of the proposed Freedom Recovery Plan, which I wrote about on Saturday. (It is the document on the bottom right.) The Hambrecht Plan involves, fundamentally, a debt-for-equity swap at the residential housing level. Like the Freedom Recovery Plan, its primary aim is to prevent foreclosures and keep people in their homes, while acknowledging that housing prices will surely have to decline further before any kind of recovery can begin. I’ll let Mr. Hambrecht take it from here.

headline.main: Saving Homeowners (Con’t): The Bill Hambrecht Plan

lead_paragraph: MOST of the nation’s 78 million baby boomers are watching their parents grow old. While investigating caretaking options for their parents, they should also be thinking about their own old age and planning how they will pay for nursing homes or home health aides for themselves, experts say. With life expectancy steadily rising, the odds are that they will eventually need some help with basic functions, like dressing or walking, maybe for decades.

abstract: Rachel Nolan, a recent Harvard graduate, visits the Shifting Careers blog to talk about her decision to move overseas to try to establish her career as a journalist.
snippet: Rachel Nolan, a recent Harvard graduate, visits the Shifting Careers blog to talk about her decision to move overseas to try to establish her career as a journalist.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I canvas the experts on where the jobs are in today’s turbulent market, one answer I always get is that there are ample opportunities, if you’re willing to leave the United States. That has started to become the refrain I sing to many job seekers who ask me for advice, especially those who are interested in travel and adventure (and who are often, though not exclusively, on the younger end of the spectrum and without family or financial commitments.) A few months ago, I started corresponding with Rachel Nolan, who graduated from Harvard in 2007 and moved to Berlin last September to see if she could break into journalism by living in a place with little competition and cheap rent. Today, we have a guest post from Ms. Nolan about how her experiment is going. — Marci

headline.main: Moving Overseas For Work and Adventure

lead_paragraph: Before heading to the beach this summer, I decided to buy a plastic watch, so I ordered one from Swatch.com. What I didn’t know was that Swatch sent information about my purchase to a company called Acerno, which runs an advertising network that reaches 80 of the top 100 Web sites. Since then, some of the ads I have seen on those sites could well have been placed by a company that specifically wanted to reach watch buyers. (There’s no way to tell if that did happen.)

abstract: An economist writes in support of a demand-side economic stimulus package.
snippet: An economist writes in support of a demand-side economic stimulus package.
lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is a professor at Princeton.With the increasing likelihood of an Obama presidency and another Democratic Congress comes the increased likelihood that macroeconomic policy in the United States will shift from bolstering the supply side of the economy to bolstering the demand side of the economy through added government spending on our badly neglected infrastructure, on alternative energy production, on health care for the hitherto underserved, on unemployment compensation and so on. The $300 billion or so economic stimulus package now being proposed by the Democratic Congress, and endorsed a few days ago by the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, is an augury of this shift.

headline.main: Does the Democrats’ Stimulus Package Make Economic Sense?

The moves are part of a $110 million overhaul plan aimed at saving as much as $100 million next year. Demand for the company’s refrigerated truck equipment in Europe and chilled display cases in North America is slowing in the financial crisis. Shares fell nearly 6 percent, closing at $17.07.

abstract: The High & Low Finance column on Friday, about possible changes in the estate tax, misstated the amount that can be excluded from estate taxes in 2011 and later years if the current law is not changed. It is $1 million, not $675,000. The column also quoted incorrectly from a report by the Tax Policy Center about the possible consequences if action is not taken. The report said that would create “grotesque tax planning initiatives,” not “grotesque tax policy initiatives.”.

abstract: CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets, the regional brokerage unit of Crédit Agricole, asked 500 senior bankers and executives to accept pay cuts of as much as 25 percent next year to avoid cutting jobs.
snippet: CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets, the regional brokerage unit of Crédit Agricole, asked 500 senior bankers and executives to accept pay cuts of as much as 25 percent next year to avoid cutting jobs.
lead_paragraph: CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets, the regional brokerage unit of Crédit Agricole, asked 500 senior bankers and executives to accept pay cuts of as much as 25 percent next year to avoid cutting jobs. The voluntary salary reduction program that was proposed for a third of the staff last week would reduce basic pay by 15 percent to 25 percent starting in January, according to the chief executive, Jonathan Slone. The participating employees would be paid the salary they forgo and might also receive a bonus payment when profit meets certain targets, he said. Those who take a 20 percent or 25 percent cut will get 17 percent or 25 percent in additional income respectively, a spokeswoman said, adding that employees who do not participate in the pay-cut plan will not lose their jobs.

abstract: Shares of Volkswagen more than doubled a day after Porsche said it had raised its stake in Volkswagen and was close to acquiring control of the company.
snippet: Shares of Volkswagen more than doubled a day after Porsche said it had raised its stake in Volkswagen and was close to acquiring control of the company.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Volkswagen more than doubled a day after Porsche said it had raised its stake in Volkswagen and was close to acquiring control of the company. Porsche, the maker of the 911 sports car, said that it had raised its stake in Volkswagen to 42.6 percent, from 35 percent, and that it had options for another 31.5 percent. If Porsche reaches a 75 percent stake, it could control every major decision at Volkswagen. Porsche said its statement was intended to give investors who had been short-selling Volkswagen stock “the opportunity to close their positions unhurriedly and without bigger risk.” Shares of Volkswagen, which is based in Wolfsburg, rose 260.48 euros, to 471 euros.

headline.main: Germany: Porsche Raises VW Stake

abstract: Six plans to stem the rising tide of foreclosures and stabilize housing prices.

lead_paragraph: In my column this week, I mention, at least in passing, six plans that I’ve read that offer ideas for helping struggling homeowners, and in so doing stem the rising tide of foreclosures and stabilize housing prices, two things that are badly needed if the financial crisis is ever going to ease. (This of course doesn’t include the plan that has been put together by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which, pathetically, the Treasury Department and the White House still haven’t approved.) I’ve also seen a handful of other plans that deserve consideration that didn’t make it into this week’s column. So without further ado, here they are, in no particular order:
